author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Jewish Deli: An American Tale Told in Pickles and Pastrami
description: “I’ll Have What She’s Having,” a traveling exhibit on the Jewish delicatessen, looks back at a vibrant institution fueled by immigration and irresistible food.
content: LOS ANGELES — The colors are fading, but the photograph of the Carnegie Deli from 2008 still calls up a world of heaping pastrami sandwiches, pungent smells of brine and smoke, and tourists lined out the door onto Seventh Avenue in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: U.S. aid chief criticizes China’s ‘absence’ in a food crisis stoked by Russia’s invasion.
description: Samantha Power, the administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development, criticized China for hoarding fertilizer and grain while millions of people in East Africa face starvation.
content: Nations that have refused to condemn Russia’s invasion of Ukraine risk accelerating a global food crisis, the United States international aid agency’s chief said on Monday, singling out China for hoarding fertilizer and grain while millions of people in East Africa face starvation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Climate Politics Are Worse Than You Think
description: If only it were just about money.
content: Texas is often hot, but not like this: Current forecasts have the temperature in Dallas hitting 109 degrees Tuesday, with highs in triple digits well into next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German’s Biggest Importer of Russian Gas Runs Through Its Credit Line
description: One of Germany’s largest energy providers is hoping that Berlin will help keep it afloat as limited gas from Russia and high prices drive its losses into the millions.
content: One of Germany’s largest energy providers, Uniper, has used up a 2 billion-euro credit line from the German state-owned investment bank and has applied for more money, it said Monday, increasing the pressure on Berlin to bail out the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Stryker
title: I Work for Midwestern Democrats, and I Know How to Win Back Voters From the G.O.P.
description: Stop letting Republicans own the issues of outsourcing and trade.
content: CHICAGO — Democrats continue to bleed support from working-class voters of all races. Many are abandoning the party for the Republicans because they think Democrats are not committed enough to fighting for their livelihood and way of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Fawcett
title: Bystander Killed Gunman 2 Minutes Into Indiana Mall Shooting
description: The gunman used a rifle to kill three people and injure two others before he was shot dead. He had spent an hour inside a mall bathroom apparently preparing for the attack.
content: A 20-year-old man carrying a rifle and pistol with access to another rifle and more than 100 rounds of ammunition was killed by a bystander two minutes after he began spraying gunfire at diners inside a mall food court in Greenwood, Ind., the authorities said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Wilting Climate Response
description: As another heat wave descends, the U.S. federal government is pulling back from the climate fight. What now?
content: Weather forecasters say that Britain this week may experience its highest temperature on record — more than 40 degrees Celsius, or about 105 degrees Fahrenheit. In response, officials in London have asked people to stay home, saying that vehicles may overheat and rail tracks may buckle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why Is Los Angeles Likely to Bring Back Mask Mandates?
description: An interview with Los Angeles County’s public health director on her plan to reinstate an indoor mask mandate on July 29.
content: As a highly infectious coronavirus variant surges nationwide, 56 of the 58 counties in California are grappling with high levels of Covid transmission, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rayne Fisher-Quann
title: How to Drop Out of College
description: Everyone but me knew it was doomed from the start.
content: I told my mother I was dropping out six weeks before Covid-19 was declared a pandemic and two weeks before Valentine’s Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Melina Delkic
title: 4 Dead in Indiana Mall Shooting, Officials Say
description: The attack by a gunman unfolded at the Greenwood Park Mall in Greenwood, Ind., on Sunday before another armed man fatally shot the assailant, city officials said.
content: Three people were killed at a mall in Greenwood, Ind., on Sunday in a shooting that ended when an armed man fatally shot the gunman, city authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Jackson, a Former Law Clerk, Returns to a Transformed Supreme Court
description: In the 22 years since she worked for Justice Stephen G. Breyer, whom she replaced last month, the court has become polarized and predictably conservative.
content: Less than two hours after the Supreme Court ended a wrenching term last month, it welcomed a new member. Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, who had been waiting in the wings since she was confirmed by the Senate in April, took two oaths of office — and joined a court in turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Fauci Says He Will ‘Almost Certainly’ Retire by January 2025
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, 81, said he expected to see out President Biden’s current term.
content: WASHINGTON — Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, who has repeatedly brushed off speculation that he would retire, says he has a time frame in mind for the end of his long government career. But those who are eager for him to go may have to wait a while: His plan is to leave by January 2025, the end of President Biden’s current term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: A teen is believed to have drowned while swimming in London’s River Thames, police say.
description: A search for the 14-year-old boy was called off after emergency crews failed to find him, as Londoners flocked to stretches of water to escape the heat.
content: A 14-year-old boy was missing on Monday evening and believed to have drowned while swimming in the River Thames, according to London’s police service, as thousands flocked to stretches of water to escape Britain’s scorching heat wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Where are the Parkland activists today?
description: The students have now lived four years in the spotlight, juggling activism, college and growing into adulthood under the media’s glare.
content: You can find Sam Fuentes these days quietly working in the New York City diamond district, hoping no one recognizes her as a Parkland massacre survivor while she sells precious metals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Amazon is giving Prime Video a face-lift.
description: The company hopes a new interface — replacing a much-maligned predecessor — will make the streaming service easier and more inviting for viewers.
content: Amazon excels at making a seemingly infinite array of retail items feel organized and accessible. So why has its streaming service, Prime Video, long had such an ugly, clunky user interface? “Amazon Prime Video’s Library Is Now Genuinely Impossible to Browse,” the online entertainment magazine Paste declared in a headline last year. As the streaming business got more competitive, notably with the arrival of glossy entrants like Disney+ and HBO Max, the poorly designed Prime Video interface stood out even more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: On Donetsk’s front line, small gains and losses impose a heavy toll.
description: In the grinding battle for eastern Ukraine’s Donetsk Province,
content: In the grinding battle for eastern Ukraine’s Donetsk Province,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Beggs
title: On Gum Drop Grapes and Other Fruits Designed to Taste Like Candy
description: Advances in plant breeding and indoor growing have led to produce that promises to be perfectly sweet.
content: IT TURNS OUT that the Garden of Eden might have been missing a few things. Today, the fruit aisle is stocked with all kinds of new temptations, and they seem to be getting sweeter. Let’s start with the grapes, namely Cotton Candy grapes (green), Gum Drop grapes (purple) and Gummyberries (red). Imagine my disappointment when, in June, I tried some grape jam-flavored Jellyberries from the company Divine Flavor and found they tasted like regular old grapes — sweet, but not Smucker’s sweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Uber agrees to pay disabled riders to settle federal lawsuit.
description: The Justice Department sued Uber last year for charging fees to passengers who took extra time to get into their vehicles.
content: Uber agreed on Monday to settle a Justice Department lawsuit that accused it of violating the Americans With Disabilities Act by charging wait fees to disabled riders who required extra time to get in their cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Treuer
title: Adrift Between My Parents’ Two Americas
description: David Treuer’s father, an Austrian immigrant, loved this country. His Native mother, born on a reservation, could never forgive it. Where does that leave him?
content: In 2015, I moved into a small back house in California, a necessary step in a divorce that was ugly and would remain so for nearly a year. At first I traded spaces with my soon-to-be ex. Then, for a year, I lived above a garage in Pomona on a pullout couch. These were awful times. One night, all three of my children were asleep, nested, innocent, seemingly safe, but I couldn’t sleep. Earlier that day 14 people were murdered and more than 20 wounded nearby in San Bernardino, and I was suddenly afraid: for my kids, for myself (as the person, impossibly, who was supposed to protect them) and for the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Democrats Navigate Nuanced Views on Abortion Among Black Voters
description: Faced with a streak of conservatism about abortion among some Black Americans, a vital constituency for President Biden, Democrats are framing the issue as part of a broader civil rights struggle.
content: As she and other faith leaders sat last month with Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the implications of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade, the Rev. Najuma Smith-Pollard, a pastor at a Black church in Los Angeles, reflected on the complex feelings in her community about abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico’s Leader Says Poverty Is His Priority. But His Policies Hurt the Poor.
description: Halfway into the president’s term, the plight of Mexico’s lower classes has only worsened. Economists say it is the result of government mismanagement of welfare programs and the economy.
content: NAUCALPAN, Mexico — The one government service this neighborhood outside Mexico City could rely on was the local elementary school run out of an abandoned train carriage. It was a vital lifeline for the residents, most of whom live in the remnants of a once-vibrant railway station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France battles wildfires that have forced thousands to evacuate.
description: Firefighters struggled to contain two blazes as a heat wave hit with full force on Monday.
content: French firefighters on Monday were battling two gigantic wildfires that have torn through nearly 60 square miles of dry pine forest in southwestern France over the past week and forced over 30,000 people to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: U.N. chief warns that humanity faces ‘collective suicide’ over climate crisis.
description: Secretary General António Guterres’ comments came as swaths of Europe faced dangerously high temperatures on Monday.
content: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, issued a dire warning on Monday to representatives from 40 countries at the Petersberg Climate Dialogue, calling for more concrete action to tackle what he called a “climate emergency.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: A Debilitating Illness, Often Ignored
description: Nearly one in 10 women experiences the chronic pain of endometriosis, but for many the symptoms are dismissed. Why is this still happening?
content: Sarah Digby barely remembers her first period, but the third is locked in her brain. She was in a seventh-grade reading class in San Antonio, her feet propped up on the desk chair in front of her, when the pain shot down from her pelvis to the back of her legs. Her feet went numb. She worried she wouldn’t be able to move. She tried to breathe slowly, to stop herself from panicking, while the pain that would define the next decade of her life set in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Carolyn Maloney Uses Personal Fortune in Primary Against Jerrold Nadler
description: The New York congresswoman lent her campaign $900,000, according to new filings released late Friday.
content: Representative Carolyn Maloney of New York holds a commanding financial advantage over her crosstown Democratic primary opponent, Representative Jerrold Nadler, thanks to a familiar benefactor: herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tatiana Stanovaya
title: Putin Thinks He’s Winning
description: And his plans go far beyond Ukraine.
content: Everything is going according to plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Spritz With a Cassis Pedigree
description: Rachael Petach’s C. Cassis, a Hudson Valley version of the French liqueur, is the base for this refreshing drink.
content: Cassis should be Rachael Petach’s middle name. A year and a half ago she introduced C. Cassis, her Hudson Valley version of the French liqueur, the essential ingredient for a Kir. Now with her local blackcurrant liqueur as a base (cassis means black currant in French), she’s introduced a spritz. Some botanicals, honey and citrus peels with seltzer added to the liqueur make for a refreshing, pleasantly fruity yet tart quencher at 5.4 percent alcohol-by-volume. You could go stronger, using it as a cocktail mixer, leaning on its affinity for gin or vodka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: The Andy Jassy Way at Amazon
description: The longtime lieutenant to Jeff Bezos has made more changes than many expected since becoming C.E.O.
content: The last of the nation’s biggest banks reported their second-quarter earnings this morning. Goldman Sachs beat expectations, as the firm’s traders were able to capitalize on volatile markets. Bank of America’s bottom line was in line with expectations, but its earnings still fell by a third from the same quarter a year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins
title: Zelensky Takes Aim at Hidden Enemy: Ukrainians Aiding Russia
description: In firing his intelligence chief and top prosecutor, President Volodymyr Zelensky signaled a more aggressive approach to a fifth column undermining Ukraine’s war effort.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Even as it engages in fierce fighting with Russia on the battlefield, Ukraine is also waging war on a different, more shadowy front: rooting out spies and collaborators in government and society who are providing crucial help to the invading forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: I Went to the State Where the First Big Fight Over Abortion Is On. Here’s What I Saw.
description: Kansas stands as the first big post-Roe political test for abortion. It’s an intense, complicated fight, with the odds stacked against reproductive-rights supporters.
content: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — When Sharon Brown answered the door of her modest town home on a recent Saturday, she was a little rude at first to the two young women standing before her, Yazmin Bruno-Valdez and Melanie Haas. They introduced themselves as volunteers with Kansans for Constitutional Freedom, a group that sounds conservative but is fighting to preserve abortion rights in the state. They were knocking on doors in Wyandotte County, one of the state’s bluer pockets, urging voters to oppose an amendment to the Kansas Constitution that would pave the way for tighter abortion restrictions, even a total ban. Ms. Bruno-Valdez offered a “Vote no” flyer explaining the measure, but Ms. Brown misunderstood which side the women were on. Rocking black fuzzy slippers and a hot pink robe, she made a disgusted face and waved the volunteers away. “I believe in abortion,” she said, moving to shut her door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: For Monkeypox Patients, Excruciating Symptoms and a Struggle for Care
description: As New York City and the federal government strain to supply enough vaccines, patients face a private battle to find treatment and relief from serious symptoms.
content: Although he was covered with lesions, it took four hours of phone calls, and then five hours in a Harlem emergency room, for Gabriel Morales to be tested for the monkeypox virus earlier this month. And that was just the beginning of his wait.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: When Miscarriages Collide With Abortion Law
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 18, 2022.
content: “I couldn’t help but cry in front of all the people at Walgreens because I felt like I was being treated like a bad person for picking up a medication to prevent an infection.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Can Batters Hit What They Can’t See? We Will Find Out.
description: Dodger Stadium at dusk can be one of the hardest places to hit in baseball. As if Clayton Kershaw and Shane McClanahan, the All-Star starters, needed any help.
content: LOS ANGELES — The All-Star Game has visited 37 different ballparks, including some more than once, since its last edition at Dodger Stadium. Ten of those sites have been razed, and three others no longer host Major League Baseball games. Chavez Ravine still glows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: The Unraveling of an Award-Winning Documentary
description: The director of “Sabaya,” about Yazidi women who had been sexually enslaved by ISIS, says that he wasn’t present for a key scene and that he substituted footage.
content: BAGHDAD — In a pivotal scene of the 2021 documentary “Sabaya,” two men rescue a young woman named Leila from a Syrian detention camp for the families of ISIS fighters, bundling her into a car and driving her to safety as shots are fired behind them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Why Is the Right Making Women Who Miscarry Suffer?
description: Some Republicans reject even lifesaving abortions.
content: It’s getting hard to keep track of all the stories of women being denied care for miscarriages and otherwise having their lives endangered because of state abortion bans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: Claes Oldenburg Dies at 93; Pop Artist Made the Everyday Monumental
description: Taking ordinary objects like hamburgers and household items, he sculpted them in unfamiliar, often imposing dimensions — what he called his “Colossal Monuments.”
content: Claes Oldenburg, the Swedish-born American Pop artist known for his monumental sculptures of everyday objects, died on Monday at his home and studio in the SoHo section of Manhattan. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sima
title: The Secret to an Elephant’s Trunk Is Skin Deep
description: The folds on an elephant’s facial appendage aren’t just for show.
content: The elephant has a secret hiding right on its nose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Karen Weise
title: Amazon C.E.O. Andy Jassy Breaks From the Bezos Way
description: Jeff Bezos’ successor has set himself apart with a hands-on approach in Washington.
content: When Jeff Bezos was chief executive of Amazon, he took an arm’s-length stance toward the company’s affairs in Washington. He rarely lobbied lawmakers. He testified only once before Congress, under the threat of subpoena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A heat wave in Europe.
content: A life-threatening heat wave is continuing its march across Western Europe this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Delta Air Lines orders 100 Boeing 737 Max planes.
description: The purchase reflects confidence that the large version of the aircraft, the Max 10, will win regulatory approval.
content: Delta Air Lines said on Monday that it planned to buy 100 of the largest variant of Boeing’s 737 Max, even as Boeing races to secure regulatory approval for that version of the jet by the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: The Parkland judge is handling her first death penalty case.
description: Judge Elizabeth A. Scherer will impose the gunman’s sentence after the jury recommends death or life in prison.
content: Judge Elizabeth A. Scherer was little known outside of the Circuit Court in Broward County, Fla., before she was randomly assigned to the Nikolas Cruz case after the Parkland shooting. Her cases had not drawn much attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
title: How Joe Manchin Left a Global Tax Deal in Limbo
description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen’s signature achievement is in jeopardy if the United States cannot ratify the tax agreement that she brokered.
content: WASHINGTON — In June, months after reluctantly signing on to a global tax agreement brokered by the United States, Ireland’s finance minister met privately with Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen, seeking reassurances that the Biden administration would hold up its end of the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Rooting Out Spies
description: President Zelensky fires two top officials to clamp down on collaborators.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Tell Me What I Don’t Want to Hear
description: NGL is only the latest anonymous-messaging platform to take off by making explicit the subtext of most social media: We’re all judging one another. Why is it so hard to resist?
content: It seems that every few years, a new anonymous-messaging platform enters the market; rapidly gains a fan base, investments and media attention; then crashes and burns. Usually, the cause is some combination of unfettered bullying, harassment or misinformation that blooms within the platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Oklahoma sees a surge in heat-related health emergencies.
description: Ambulances in Tulsa and Oklahoma City have taken dozens of patients to hospitals with heat exhaustion or heat stroke, a significant increase over previous summers.
content: Ambulance crews in Oklahoma’s largest cities are grappling with a surge in heat-related health emergencies as daily highs continue to top 100 degrees across much of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Why Europe Is Becoming a Heat Wave Hot Spot
description: This year’s scorching weather is in keeping with a trend. Scientists say a number of factors, including changes in the jet stream, are in play.
content: Two months ago, France experienced its hottest May on record, with record highs in some cities. Last month, France was blistered again, by a spring heat wave that also affected Spain, Italy and other countries. Then, this month, Poland and other parts of Eastern Europe suffered during a spell of extreme heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Bad Bunny Holds at No. 1, With a Surprise Brent Faiyaz LP Close Behind
description: The Puerto Rican superstar earns his fifth week at the top, but “Wasteland,” an unexpected drop from the Maryland R&B singer, made a statement.
content: The top album on the Billboard chart this week is Bad Bunny’s “Un Verano Sin Ti,” a streaming juggernaut that is notching its fifth time at No. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Gotytom Gebreslase of Ethiopia wins women’s world championship marathon.
description: Judith Korir of Kenya won silver, and Lonah Chemtai Salpeter of Israel won bronze. All three medalists bested the world championship marathon record time set by Paula Radcliffe in 2005.
content: The world championship women’s marathon was a race filled with races. Leaders took off at a pace that was five minutes faster than the world-championship record. Then they slowed. Then they surged. Then they slowed again. It was a fartlek workout disguised as a marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani
title: Federal Judge Temporarily Blocks Enforcement of L.G.B.T.Q. Protections
description: The ruling sided with 20 state attorneys general who sued the Biden administration over guidelines on rights for gay and transgender workers and students.
content: A federal judge on Friday temporarily blocked the Biden administration from enforcing directives that extended civil rights protections to L.G.B.T.Q. students and workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: England’s Transportation Network Strains Under the Heat
description: Part of the tarmac at London’s Luton Airport had to be repaired after scorching temperatures caused a “surface defect.”
content: LONDON — England on Monday was facing the possibility of serious disruption to its transportation networks as temperatures were poised to creep to unprecedented new highs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: How to Improve on Ice Cream Cones? Churros.
description: ChikaLicious Dessert Bar’s churro cone is filled with a confection of berries, graham crackers and marshmallow.
content: Churros, the irresistibly crunchy fluted cruller strips from the Iberian Peninsula that are often snacks and desserts in Spain, Portugal, Mexico and across Latin America, pair perfectly with ice cream. At ChikaLicious Dessert Bar, Chika and Don Tillman’s sweet spot in the East Village, they’re being twisted into crisp ice cream cones. They’re filled with oat milk ice cream called S’more Mother Earth, made with berries, graham crackers and a burnished marshmallow topping; available by reservation only.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: An M.L.B. Draft High on Name Recognition and Star Power
description: Jackson Holliday, son of the seven-time All-Star Matt, went No. 1 and Druw Jones, son of Andruw, went No. 2. But Kumar Rocker’s going third was Day 1’s biggest surprise.
content: LOS ANGELES — The Major League Baseball draft is not about name recognition or instant gratification. No prospect has played in a bowl game or busted a bracket in March. Even for the top choices, the dimmer lights of the minor leagues await.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel and Isabella Simonetti
title: 3 takeaways from big banks’ latest financial reports.
description: Wall Street bank executives said consumer spending was up, markets were volatile and they did not think the economy was headed for a recession.
content: Investors have been sifting through the first batch of company earnings this quarter to monitor the chances of a recession, the state of consumer spending and the outlook for the markets. Reports from the nation’s biggest banks at the start of “earnings season,” as Wall Street calls it, sent mixed signals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: Eight U.S. House Offices File for the Right to Unionize
description: The petitions are the first step for congressional aides to negotiate their working conditions with the same legal protections that other federal workers enjoy.
content: WASHINGTON — Aides to eight of the most progressive members of the House filed petitions on Monday to form unions in their offices, the first substantial action by congressional staff to organize collectively to bargain for better work conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s what to watch at the world championships on Monday.
description: Watch the indomitable Faith Kipyegon take on the 1,500 meters in the evening.
content: Women’s 1,500 meters: 10:50 p.m. Eastern (Peacock)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: Imran Khan Dominates Punjab Vote, Deepening Pakistan Turmoil
description: Mr. Khan’s political party won 15 of the 20 seats in the country’s most populous province, which has often served as a bellwether for national politics.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Less than four months after Prime Minister Imran Khan was ousted from power in Pakistan, his party has won a sweeping victory in elections in the most populous province, proving that Mr. Khan remains a powerful force and adding to the political uncertainty that has embroiled the country since his defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles
title: Five takeaways from the first day of the Parkland school shooting trial.
description: Jurors are hearing evidence about aggravating factors that might warrant recommending the death penalty for the gunman, who has pleaded guilty to 17 counts of murder.
content: The first day of the trial over whether the gunman who killed 17 people in Parkland, Fla., in 2018 should be sentenced to death or life in prison included disturbing videos taken inside classrooms where several students were shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Kodak Black Is Arrested on Drug Charges in Florida
description: The authorities said they found dozens of oxycodone tablets and $75,000 in cash while searching the rapper’s car after he was pulled over in Fort Lauderdale on Friday.
content: The rapper Kodak Black was arrested on Friday in South Florida on felony drug charges, the authorities said. It was the latest in a long string of legal woes for Black, 25, who was serving prison time on weapons charges when President Donald J. Trump commuted his sentence on his last day in office last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Art of the Serving Set
description: The ceramist Jono Pandolfi, whose works are in restaurants like Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s Nougatine, will sell special editions monthly.
content: The work of Jono Pandolfi, a ceramist based in Union City, N.J., adorns the tables of a number of restaurants, among them Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s Nougatine. This month, he is offering a serving set designed for Mr. Vongerichten’s Seeds & Weeds, a restaurant soon to open in the Tin Building market in the Seaport District. The set is part of a series of special editions offered monthly; the next one will be released on Aug. 5. The Vongerichten set includes an oval red platter and three white bowls of varying sizes with hand-painted red stripes. The glazes Mr. Pandolfi applies to his clay pieces provide a look that’s at once rustic yet polished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: The Unlikeliest of All-Stars Makes Every Pitch Look Good
description: Jose Trevino of the Yankees did not start catching until college, but is so good at manipulating umpires with his pitch framing that he sometimes fools his own pitchers.
content: Jose Trevino remembers suiting up, squatting down, and catching for the first time at Oral Roberts University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: How to Grill Israeli-Style, Live From Laser Wolf
description: The chef Michael Solomonov and the author Eden Grinshpan will cook from the rooftop of the Brooklyn location of the restaurant.
content: To understand what might be different about the way grilling is done in Israel compared with the typical American backyard, it will pay to tune into a rooftop session for the 92nd Street Y by the Israeli chef Michael Solomonov from his Brooklyn restaurant Laser Wolf, where charcoal reigns. author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Banner Year for Bristol Bay’s Sockeye Salmon Harvest
description: This year’s catch in southeast Alaska is expected to be among the largest on record; Pride of Bristol Bay is a reliable source for delivery in September.
content: The sockeye salmon harvest in the Bristol Bay area of southeast Alaska is expected to be among the largest on record. State officials are reporting a run of 74 million fish, mostly from Bristol Bay, during a season that started on June 1 and continues until early August. Bristol Bay, the world’s largest source for wild sockeye salmon, is a sustainably managed resource where thousands of local fishermen work on small boats. The salmon are smaller than king salmon, with firmer, succulent, characteristically deep red-orange flesh. The fish are widely shipped for sale in stores, online and in restaurants. Among the reliable sources for home cooks is Pride of Bristol Bay, which has started accepting orders for delivery in September. They sell the fish in 10- and 20-pound lots, either filleted sides of about 1.25 pounds each ($219.90 for 10 pounds, $399.80 for 20), or in individual 5- to 7-ounce portions ($229.90 for 10 pounds, $419.80 for 20).

content: One of my fustiest and most out-of-touch opinions is that progressives need to rediscover the political power of civil liberties. Such declarations usually accompany free speech controversies — some professor gets canceled at some college with an 11 percent acceptance rate, everyone starts tweeting about who has the right to say what in which settings, and by the time it’s all forgotten two days later, nobody really has any clarity on what freedom of speech actually means. I will admit that as something of a free speech absolutist, I am not immune to such temptations. But I also acknowledge that these episodes don’t really have much to do with civil liberties at all. Instead, they use a vaguely defined ethos of free speech as a prop in an ongoing power struggle between two sides that have both largely lost the plot.

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Officials Aren’t Sounding the Alarm on Covid
description: As the BA.5 subvariant drives a spike, many public health leaders aren’t cracking down
content: The BA.5 subvariant, now the cause of at least two-thirds of U.S. cases, is driving a Covid spike in some 40 states. But Americans, exhausted from repeated surge warnings, are less likely than ever to wear masks or avoid crowds. Many U.S. health officials aren’t speaking out against such practices.
source.name: The New York Times
